desc.size: Large shrub or small tree, 4 - 9 m tall, trunk diameter 15 - 30 cm. Crown broadly rounded.

part.partText: gray, smooth on young trees, becoming rough and furrowed with age; diamond-shaped patterns often develop due to a fungus.
slender, reddish purple to orange brown, becoming lighter with age; at first downy, becoming smooth; widely forking.

alternate, with 5 - 8 mm long, downy leafstalks; dull green above, gray or whitish and net-veined beneath, 3 - 10 cm long, 1 - 3 cm wide, elliptical, broadest at or above the middle, base tapering, tip short-pointed; margins smooth, slightly toothed, or somewhat wavy; firm, gray-hairy.

either male or female, borne on separate trees (dioecious); in slightly hairy, cylindrical catkins on short, leafy stalks; female catkins loosely flowered, to 6 cm long, scales pale yellow and pink-tipped, ovary hairy; male catkins densely flowered, to 3 cm long, stamens 2, anthers yellow; insect- and wind-pollinated.

a capsule; in elongated clusters; stalked, light brown, 5 - 9 mm long, flask-shaped, long-pointed, slightly hairy; seeds dark purple or green, with long, white, silky hairs attached; dispersed by wind and water.

similarSpecies.comments: Salix bebbiana is distinguished from most other willows in the Chicago Region by having leaf margins that are not distinctly toothed or down-curved (revolute). Salix discolor and S. x conifera are similar but lack gray-hairy leaves.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Salix bebbiana is characteristically found along streams and lakes. In the Chicago Region, it is locally frequent in the shrub zone of boggy ground, where there has been disturbance. Also found in wet prairies, fens, and moist uplands.

notes.comments: The wood is used for canes, baseball bats, lampposts, and furniture.

etymology.comments: Salix is the Latin word for willow. Bebbiana refers to the American willow specialist Michael Schuck Bebb (1833-1895).
